messages.content: Hi (:star) I’m <PERSON>. This is your safe space to share your thoughts without judgment. What’s on your mind today?
I have a big presentation next week and I'm freaking out (:worried). I can't stop thinking that I'll mess up.

That sounds stressful. Public speaking can trigger a lot of fear, but acknowledging it is the first step. Do you know what part of the presentation scares you the most—the speaking itself, or fear of judgment from others?
Both. I hate when people look at me. Yesterday, my friend <PERSON> said I looked pale while practicing at home. (:happy)

It’s understandable. Physical reactions like feeling pale or shaky are normal signs of anxiety. They don’t define your ability—they’re just your body reacting to stress. How did it feel hearing <PERSON>'s comment?
Embarrassing. I felt like she was judging me, even if she meant it as a joke.
That's valid. Anxiety can amplify perceived judgment. Maybe practicing in a supportive space—like just you and <PERSON>, or recording yourself—could help reduce that fear.
I tried recording yesterday on my phone (<PHONE_NUMBER>) but I got distracted by notifications and deleted the video. (:sweat_smile)
Technology distractions are real! Maybe try a quiet room, airplane mode, or even using a different device. Small changes like that can make practice more effective.
Good idea. Also, I found some tips online, but there were too many steps.
That’s common; too many steps can feel overwhelming. Would you like me to suggest a simple three-step prep routine for your presentation?
Yes, please.

Here’s one:

Outline your main points clearly on paper.

Practice speaking out loud for 5 minutes each day.

Visualize the audience reacting positively.

Keeping it small can reduce stress.
Ok, I can do that. But I also keep thinking about last year when I stuttered during a presentation with <PERSON> on <DATE>.
That memory can make you anxious, but it doesn’t predict the future. Everyone stutters sometimes, and it’s okay. What matters is how you respond—breathing, pausing, and continuing confidently.
True, I also tried watching YouTube tutorials but I got distracted by funny videos.
It happens (:happy). Humor can be a relief. Maybe schedule a focused 10-minute session for practice, then allow a short break for leisure videos as a reward.
I like that. Also, my mom told me to "just calm down and speak normally," but it made me more nervous.
That's common. Simple advice can feel dismissive when anxiety is intense. Your feelings are valid, and it's okay to need structured support instead of just reassurance.
Yeah, I also thought about emailing my speech draft to my mentor.
That’s a great idea. Getting feedback before the presentation can boost confidence. Even a short note asking for quick comments can help.
Ok, I’ll try that tonight. I also plan to practice in the small classroom at <LOCATION> University where we’ll present next week.
Perfect. Familiarity with the space can reduce uncertainty. You're taking concrete steps to control what you can control.
I also feel nervous about eye contact. My friend <PERSON> said I look away too much, and I get anxious (:worried).
Eye contact can be practiced gradually. Maybe start by looking at friendly faces or slightly above the audience's heads. Little adjustments over time can build confidence.
I'll try that. Also, I noticed I type fast and make typos when I take notes for my speech, like "environment" instead of "environment" (:embarrassed).
No worries—small typos don’t matter in the big picture. The key is clarity of ideas and delivery, not perfection in typing.
Thanks, <PERSON>. Even talking here makes me feel a bit less anxious.
I'm glad (:happy) you're already taking steps—planning, practicing, visualizing. That's resilience in action. Keep trusting yourself, and remember every small step counts.
Ok, I'll practice tonight and maybe email my mentor tomorrow. Wish me luck!
Good luck (:star). You've got this. Remember: anxiety is natural, but preparation and self-compassion can transform it into confidence.
